key_points: More than three months after his resignation due to sexual harassment allegations, former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo remains a political presence.
A state assembly report found "overwhelming evidence" Cuomo engaged in sexual harassment and was not transparent about COVID-19 deaths in nursing homes.
Cuomo denies sexual misconduct allegations and insists his book deal followed ethical norms.
Despite his political downfall, Cuomo's future actions and influence in politics remain a topic of speculation among New York politicians.
Cuomo's public communication is mostly through his lawyer, Rita Glavin, and spokesman, Rich Azzopardi, who defend him against allegations.
New Gov. Kathy Hochul is seen as bringing a more collaborative era, but Cuomo's presence continues to loom over New York politics.
There is speculation about Cuomo potentially running for state attorney general, a position he held from 2007 to 2010.
Skepticism exists about the depth of Cuomo's financial resources due to his legal expenses.
Cuomo's potential political comeback is fueled by rumors and media speculation despite his current sidelined status.
Cuomo and his team continue to challenge the findings of the investigation led by New York Attorney General Letitia James.
spokespersons: Jay Jacobs (New York's state Democratic Party chairman)
